statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.description: Tim Duncan had 24 points and 16 rebounds, and the San Antonio Spurs pulled away in the fourth quarter for a 102-93 win over the Denver Nuggets on Tuesday night.
article.headline: Duncan powers Spurs to fourth straight road win
article.linkText: Spurs make it eight straight by burying Nuggets
article.story:
DENVER (AP) -- Determined to double-team Tim Duncan in the fourth quarter and make the other San Antonio players beat them, the Denver Nuggets got what they wanted. The other Spurs got what they wanted, too: wide-open shots. While Duncan finished with 24 points and 16 rebounds, the Spurs used final-quarter contributions from Antonio Daniels and Charles Smith to beat the Nuggets 102-93 Tuesday night. Daniels had 10 of his 16 points in the final period as the Spurs posted their eighth straight victory and fourth in a row on the road. San Antonio outscored Denver 31-21 in the fourth period. Asked about passing the ball in the final period, during which he had three assists, Duncan said, "I have to. What they are going to give up we have to take advantage of. They came on the doubles, and our shooters were wide open. I'll take our shooters wide open any night." Spurs coach Gregg Popovich said his team "brought some energy in the fourth quarter. We played pretty good defense in the fourth, and Tim did a great job of finding people off of the double team." Denver interim coach Mike Evans concurred. "What really hurt us was having to double-team Duncan and allowing Charles Smith to hit some big shots," he said. "You can see why they're a very good team, especially with that big guy in the middle (Duncan)." The Spurs also enjoyed a huge advantage at the foul line, making 27-of-35 free throws compared to Denver's 4-of-5. The Spurs made 14-of-16 free throws in the final period, while Denver didn't go to the line. "That's wild, that's unbelievable," Nuggets guard Nick Van Exel said. "It's just tough when you play hard and you get dominated in one area, and that was the free-throw area." Van Exel had 25 points and 15 assists, while Voshon Lenard added 24 points and Raef LaFrentz 20. The Nuggets led for the last time on ex-Spur Avery Johnson's basket in the lane that made it 76-75 with 9:54 left. Daniels then hit a 3-pointer, as did Terry Porter, and Smith scored seven straight San Antonio points to make it 90-82 with 5:44 to go. Denver cut the deficit to four, 93-89, on Van Exel's short jumper, but Duncan, who leads the NBA with 19 double-doubles, hit a 10-foot turnaround jumper for a 95-89 lead with 1:58 left. Daniels added a fast-break layup and Porter made two free throws. The Nuggets dropped to 2-1 under Evans, who was subbing for Dan Issel. Issel served the third game of his four-game suspension for making an insensitive ethnic remark to a fan. Van Exel had 10 points in the first quarter as Denver took a 27-26 lead. The Nuggets mounted an early 9-0 run, including fastbreak baskets by LaFrentz and Shawnelle Scott and a 3-pointer by Van Exel, to move to a 16-8 lead. Seven straight points by the Spurs, capped by Porter's 3-pointer, brought San Antonio back. Duncan had eight points and eight rebounds in the period, including a tip-in to end the period and start an 11-0 flurry that carried into the second quarter. Bruce Bowen's 3-pointer gave the Spurs their biggest lead of the half, 35-27. Denver countered with a 12-2 run, including what amounted to a four-point play when Calbert Cheaney made a reverse layup and was fouled. He missed the free throw, but LaFrentz tipped it in. San Antonio then scored seven straight points, including another 3-pointer by Porter, and led 49-45 at halftime. Lenard scored 10 of Denver's 19 points during a six-minute span of the third quarter, and the Nuggets carried a 72-71 lead into the final period.

Game notes
The teams meet again Friday night in San Antonio. For Denver, it will mark two straight games against the Spurs. San Antonio plays Portland at home Wednesday night before facing Denver again. ... Even though a head coach is suspended, the wins and losses still go toward his record. ... The Spurs (18-4) have not lost this month. ... The Nuggets, who attempted a season-high 99 shots, matched franchise lows for free throws made and attempted in a game.
